Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)

result.execSummary:
The defendant Jamie L Etheridge was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • OWI (5th or 6th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Washington County Clerk of Circuit Court

superMiscConds.notes: If extended supervision is revoked or will discharge with outstanding financial obligations due, a civil judgment shall be entered for the balance due. Restitution is set at $0; restitution hearing may be requested if it is determined that the insurance company has not paid full amount due.

Defendant shall maintain absolute sobriety; defendant shall not possess or consume any alcohol or controlled substances without a valid prescription. Defendant shall submit to random screens of blood/breath/urine to determine compliance. Defendant shall not enter establishments where the primary purpose is sale/service of alcohol. Defendant shall not associate with known drug users or be present where drugs are illegally purchased/sold/consumed.

Defendant shall participate in all counseling and/or treatment programs directed by the probation agent, including AODA assessment/treatment.   Defendant shall provide a biological specimen for DNA analysis.  Defendant has the right to request expungement of DNA analysis in writing through the Department of Justice. Defendant shall obtain/maintain full time employment and/or school. Defendant shall maintain a stable residence. Defendant shall inform medical professionals providing care of addiction history.
